title: Express Talk: Gold, Clay, & Parchment: Making Art in Renaissance Italy
hero_caption: Benedetto Buglioni and workshop. Adoration of the Shepherds, about 1520. Gift of Kate S. Buckingham, Lucy Maud Buckingham Memorial Collection.
description:
Italian Renaissance art is known for its rich materials and fine workmanship that often inspire the question: How did they do that?

Whether locally-sourced or imported across oceans, the stuff of Italian Renaissance art—and the way artists put it together in the workshop—has a fascinating story to tell. Facilitated by Chloé Pelletier, Mellon COSI Research Fellow in the department of European Painting and Sculpture, this talk will explore these stories through a deep dive into the materials and techniques of three diverse Italian Renaissance objects: a gold-ground painting, a ceramic altarpiece, and a parchment choir book.

Persons with disabilities who would like to request an accessibility accommodation for an Art Institute program are encouraged to send an email to access@artic.edu two weeks in advance of the program. 

Please note that the image on this page is for reference purposes only and may not be featured during the gallery talk.
